Since it's been brought up—in much
the way one's dinner gets brought up by
a quick punch in the stomach—let's consider the relationship of a student newspaper to the student government that
funds it (or, as with the N-L, only partially
funds it).
Newspapers are in the business of
acting as a critical review of the local
governing officials. They must have some
independence from these officials, or else
they cannot perform this function; and this
is as true of the Podunk U. Review as it is
of the most serious muckraking daily.
As it stands now, the Chairman of
the Student Activities Commission has the
N-L by the short ones. She can "freeze"
our funds on the sole basis that she finds
our conduct "irresponsible," and she
doesn't have to thaw them out unless her
executive board. or the Student Council,
overturns her decision.
Clearly the term "irresponsible"
needs a mutually agreed-upon definition,
and the Chairman's powers need redefinition, period. The N-L's responsibility is
to the student body, not to one elected
official.
Different editorial boards in
different years have had differing understandings of this responsibility -in 1975,

Paper) pissed off the SAC mightily by
refusing to cover Council doings.

view, and denied the .V-L, all S6000 of its
